discussion.content:
I think the confusion here is because of the wording. Think of the question as "In which of the following should the work plan and recovery procedure be documented [for the technician's reference]?"

The question isn't trying to say that the technician is doing the documenting. Rather, where should he look to complete the aforementioned procedure.

SoPs is the answer because it says to document the procedure to achieve a change, while that change in itself which is/was the Replacement of Router for instance would be documented into the change management.

comments.content: Though if the new service pack means that the device needs to be used or managed differently, then it would seem to make sense to change SOPs when necessary. No point using this year's tech, in last year's way.

discussion.content: SOP's are prewritten rules to follow to complete a task. The only time you document anything in a SOP is if the procedure to complete a certain task has changed. ex. if a company normally telnets to routers then they decide to change that SOP to using SSH then that woulr be documented no configuration changes will be in a SOP. On the other hand Change management is where you would document when you SSH into a router and made configuration changes. A TACAS+ will keep copies of all ASCII keys used to configuration that info can then be cut and pasted into a Changemangement DOcumentation.

comments.content: I agree with you after rereading the question. If the term procedure wasn't included in the question, it would most definitely be Change Management.

discussion.content: The given answer is correct simply because of the key word that was slipped in, "Procedure". If this word was not included, then i would definitely assume Change Management.
On the A+ this is B. I cant get myself to change it to C
This question seems to start off talking about an upgrade, then asks, "In which of the following should the work plan and recovery procedure be documented?" This refers to the SOP.
Should be b
Hello --> Standard Operating Procedure (SOP), but why?

why is it not B?
It literally should be B

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to upgrade a production Windows server to the latest service pack. In which of the following should the work plan and recovery procedure be documented?

discussion.content: As others have said, AC is the latest, but it is 5 GHz only. The protocol right before that would be 802.11n, which supports both 2.4 GHz and 5Ghz. It would be the fastest protocol that would support newer and older network clients, out of the options.

Apparently all these questions had “N” as an answer even though “AC” support both. After a bit of digging I found out why: Apparently a 802.11ac router uses “ac” ONLY for 5Ghz and 2.4Ghz is still used on the “n”. So 802.11N makes more sense as it uses 5Ghz and 2.4 Ghz on the same standard.

B. ac is right answer. it is "maximum speed possbile" and also backward compatible with "b,g,n".

https://www.semiconductorstore.com/blog/2014/WiFi-standards-802-11a-b-g-n-vs-802-11ac-Which-is-Best/806/#:~:text=802.11ac%20offers%20backward%20compatibility,450%20Mbps%20on%202.4%20GHz.
AC does not support 2.4GHZ, supports both.

i think the key is "The solution needs to support new and legacy wireless network clients" legacy & network clients. 802.11N, the wireless LAN IEEE draft standard that uses multiple input/multiple output technology to boost Wi-Fi speeds to over 100Mbps, is “backward compatible” with today's 802.11a, 11b, and 11g networks. its the backward compatible part that makes it good for legacy equip
i thought ac was the latest technology
whats wrong with AC?

questions.question_text:
A network technician is installing a wireless solution. The solution needs to support new and legacy wireless network clients at the maximum possible speed.
Which of the following wireless standards should the technician install?
Which of the following steps is a network technician MOST likely to take to secure a new network printer? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Why doesn't physical security matter for a printer? It could, especially if people are using it to print sensitive documents.

comments.content:
When you connect your printer to the network, you have the ability to log into the printer using the default credentials so you can adjust ip information and such.
As far as disabling unnecessary services, many times printers come with features that are unneeded, so you should disable them so they cant be exploited by an attacker.

"Network devices come with default credentials. Changing default credentials should be the first step in hardening a new device." Disabling unnecessary services is mentioned right after this in the book.
-Mike Meyers, Network+ Certification Exam N10-006, pg. 685

discussion.content: Confused with these answers, someone explain, thanks

questions.question_text: A technician is installing a new wireless badging system on a hospital network. The requirements of the badging system are for it to have its own SSID and low power levels. The badging system has to cover 99.9% of the hospital. Which of the following is the BEST action to take to meet the system requirements?

comments.content: Yeah! because if you are going to need 99.9% coverage at LOW power levels you are gonna need a heck of a lot of waps!

discussion.content: Option 'A' is correct.

choices.C: Move the WAPs closer to the more populated area

questions.question_text: The backup server connects to a NAS device using block-level storage over Ethernet. The performance is very slow, however, and the network technician suspects the performance issues are network related. Which of the following should the technician do to improve performance?

discussion.content: Block storage is a category of data storage mostly used in storage area network (SAN) environments, where data is saved in huge volumes known as blocks. Each block in block storage is configured by a storage administrator and acts like an individual hard drive.

None of these answers really fit. NAS (network attached storage) utilizes file type storage and isn't compatible with block level storage. Converting the NAS to a SAN (Storage Area Network) would work much better as a fix.

comments.content: I agree. I even looked in the book. I am not sure but questions can be contested to compTIA
Converting the NAS to a SAN (tens of thousands of dollars) would be incredibly expensive compared to changing to jumbo frames (free).

discussion.content: Wait, I thought that NAS used file-level storage and that SAN used block-level. Is that incorrect?

iSCSI storage benefits from jumbo frames. If jumbo frames are used, data is less likely to be fragmented into smaller 1500-byte frames. When packet fragmentation occurs, the higher-level protocol of IP at layer 3 must reassemble the fragments. The reassembly of these fragmented packets causes latency and higher CPU utilization. Latency is the enemy of SANs.
Enabling jumbo frames is the only suitable answer, you're reducing packet overhead by enabling jumbo frames.

choices.D: Encapsulate the storage traffic in a GRE tunnel
choices.C: Enable jumbo frames on the NAS and server
choices.A: Utilize UDP to eliminate packet overhead
choices.B: Turn off MDIX settings on the NAS and server switchports
